revisions.rev:
{{Infobox NCAA team season |Mode = football |Year = 2009 |Team = Florida Gators |Image = Script ``Gators``.png |ImageSize = |Conference = Southeastern Conference |Division = Eastern Division |ShortConference = SEC |CoachRank = 3 |APRank = 3 |Record = 13â1 |ConfRecord = 8â0 |HeadCoach = [[Urban Meyer]] |HCYear=5th |OffCoach = [[Steve Addazio]] |OCYear= |DefCoach = [[Charlie Strong]] |DCYear= |OScheme =[[Offensive philosophy (American football)#The Spread|Spread Option]] |DScheme =[[3-3-5]] |StadiumArena =[[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]] |Champion = Sugar Bowl Champions
SEC Eastern Division Champions |BowlTourney = [[2010 Sugar Bowl|Sugar Bowl]] vs. [[2009 Cincinnati Bearcats football team|Cincinnati]] |BowlTourneyResult = W 51â24 |ConfChamp=[[2009 SEC Championship Game|SEC Championship Game]] vs. [[2009 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama]] |ConfChampResult= L 13â32 |uniform=File:SEC-Uniform-UF-2009.png }} {{2009 SEC football standings}} The '''2009 Florida Gators football team''' represented the [[University of Florida]] in the sport of [[American football]] during the [[2009 NCAA Division I FBS football season|2009 college football season]]. The Gators competed in the [[Division I (NCAA)#Football Bowl Subdivision|Football Bowl Subdivision]] (FBS) of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] (NCAA) and the Eastern Division of the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC), and played their home games at [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]] on the university's [[Gainesville, Florida]] campus. They were led by fifth-year head coach [[Urban Meyer]], who coached the Gators to a first-place finish in the SEC East, a 51–24 [[2010 Sugar Bowl|Sugar Bowl]] victory over the [[Cincinnati Bearcats football|Cincinnati Bearcats]], and an overall win-loss record of 13–1 (.929). With senior quarterback [[Tim Tebow]] and eleven defensive starters returning, the Gators had hoped to repeat as back-to-back national champions following their [[2009 BCS National Championship|BCS National Championship]] at the end of the [[2008 Florida Gators football team|2008 season]]. They finished with an undefeated 12–0 regular season, their first since [[1995 Florida Gators football team|1995]], but the Gators' 32–13 loss to the [[2009 Alabama Crimson Tide football team|Alabama Crimson Tide]] in the SEC Championship Game derailed their national title hopes, and forced them to settle for a berth in the Sugar Bowl. At the conclusion of the 2009 season, the Gators were ranked No. 3 in both major polls. On December 26, 2009, Gators athletic director [[Jeremy Foley]] announced that Urban Meyer would step down as the team's head coach for health and family reasons.{{cite web|url=http://gatorzone.com/story.php?id=17169|title=UF's Urban Meyer Steps Down as Head Football Coach|accessdate=27 December 2009}} The following day, Meyer stated that he would instead take an indefinite leave of absence, allowing him to resume his position as the head coach. Meyer returned to coach the Gators in spring practice in March 2010. {{TOClimit|2}} == Previous season == In the 2008 season, the Gators went 11–1 in the regular season, suffering their only loss to [[2008 Ole Miss Rebels football team|Ole Miss]] in Gainesville. Their post-season success included a win over No. 1–ranked Alabama Crimson Tide in the [[2008 SEC Championship Game]], followed by a win over the No. 1–ranked Oklahoma Sooners in the [[2009 BCS Championship Game]]. The Gators finished the 2008 season with a 13–1 record and ranked No. 1 in the AP and USA Today Coaches Polls. It was the third national championship for the Gators. ==Pre-season== On January 11, 2009 during the national championship celebration at the University of Florida, quarterback [[Tim Tebow]] announced his intention to return for his senior season,{{cite web|url=http://myespn.go.com/blogs/ncfnation/0-5-211/Tebow-wants-to-do-it-all-over-again.html|title=Tebow wants to do it all over again|publisher=ESPN.com|date=2009-01-11|accessdate=2009-01-11}} followed on January 15 by linebacker [[Brandon Spikes]] intention to return as well. With Spikes' return, the entire two-deep of the Gators defense was set to return for the 2009 season. One major loss was All-America wide receiver [[Percy Harvin]], who opted to leave the University of Florida to enter the [[2009 NFL Draft]]. The Gators also lost offensive coordinator and quarterback coach [[Dan Mullen]], who became the head coach at [[Mississippi State]] following [[Sylvester Croom]]'s resignation. Former offensive line coach Steve Addazio was named as Mullen's replacement, with Scot Loeffler hired to take on the role of quarterback coach. The Gators played their spring scrimmage on April 18, 2009, with the Orange winning. Florida was voted #1 in both the preseason [[Coaches' Poll|USA Today Coaches' Poll]] and the [[AP Poll]]. The Gators received the highest ever percentage of preseason #1 votes in the history of the AP Poll, which began in 1950.[http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20090822/ap_on_sp_co_ne/fbc_t25_college_fb_poll Gators are No. 1 in AP preseason Top 25 poll]{{cite web|title=Gators shrug off top ranking in preseason coaches' poll|url=http://www2.tbo.com/content/2009/aug/07/071104/florida-tops-usa-today-preseason-coaches-poll/sports-colleges/|work=|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5jc4nvGYz|archivedate=2009-09-07|deadurl=no|accessdate=2009-09-06}} Most of the pre-game talk surrounded comments made by Volunteer's head coach [[Lane Kiffin]]. The Gators quickly took at 31â0 lead in the first quarter before going on to win 41â7. Manuel]] (Dustin Hopkins kick), 8:11. ''Gators 37â10.'' }} In the regular season finale, the Gators blew by the Seminoles 37â10. A new attendance record at [[Ben Hill Griffin Stadium]] was set with 90,907 present.[http://gatorzone.com/story.php?id=17048 Gatorzone.com: No. 1 Florida Defeats FSU, 37â10, on Senior Day] ===SEC Championship Game vs. Alabama=== {{main|2009 SEC Championship Game}} {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=#1 Gators |R1=3 ||R2=10 ||R3=0 ||R4=0 ||RT= |Home='''#2 Crimson Tide''' |H1=9 ||H2=10 ||H3=7 ||H4=6 ||HT= |date=December 5, 2009 |time= 4:00 p.m. ET |TV= [[SEC on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Verne Lundquist]] (playâbyâplay), [[Gary Danielson]] (color commentator), [[Tracy Wolfson]] (sideline reporter) |bg2= #e6e6e6 |referee= Matt Austin |stadium= [[Georgia Dome]], [[Atlanta, Georgia]] |attendance= 75,514 |weather= None (Domed stadium) |stats= ; Pregame Line * â5.0 ; Leading passers * FLA â [[Tim Tebow]] â 20/35, 247 yards, 1 TD, 1 INT * ALA â [[Greg McElroy]] â 12/18, 239 yards, 1 TD ; Leading rushers * FLA â Tim Tebow â 10 rushes, 63 yards * ALA â [[Mark Ingram, Jr.|Mark Ingram]] â 28 rushes, 113 yards, 3 TD ; Leading receivers * FLA â [[Aaron Hernandez]] â 8 receptions, 85 yards * ALA â [[Marquis Maze]] â 5 receptions, 96 yards |scoring= ; 1st Quarter * ALA â [[Leigh Tiffin]], 48 yard field goal, 10:37. ''Crimson Tide 3â0.'' * ALA â [[Mark Ingram, Jr.|Mark Ingram]], 7 yard run (PAT failed), 5:33. ''Crimson Tide 9â0.'' * FLA â [[Caleb Sturgis]], 48 yard field goal, 0:28. ''Crimson Tide 9â3.'' ; 2nd Quarter * ALA â Leigh Tiffin, 34 yard field goal, 6:03. ''Crimson Tide 12â3.'' * FLA â [[David Nelson (American football)|David Nelson]], 23 yard pass from [[Tim Tebow]] (Caleb Sturgis kick), 4:31. ''Crimson Tide 19â13.'' ; 3rd Quarter * ALA â [[Colin Peek]] 17 yard pass from [[Greg McElroy]] (Leigh Tiffin kick), 9:53. ''Crimson Tide 26â13.'' ; 4th Quarter * ALA â Mark Ingram 1 yard run (2PT attempt failed), 13:49. ''Crimson Tide 32â13.'' }} In a rematch of [[2009 SEC Championship Game|last year's SEC Championship Game]], the Crimson Tide handed the Gators their only loss of the season. Alabama running back [[Mark Ingram, Jr.|Mark Ingram]] scored three touchdowns in the 32â13 win. ===Sugar Bowl vs. Cincinnati=== {{main|2010 Sugar Bowl}} {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''#5 Gators''' |R1=9 |R2=21 |R3=14 |R4=7 |Home=#4 Bearcats |H1=0 |H2=3 |H3=7 |H4=14 |stadium=[[Louisiana Superdome]], [[New Orleans, Louisiana]] |date= January 1, 2010 |time= 8:30 p.m. ET |weather= None (Domed stadium) |referee= Jack Folliard ([[Pacific-10 Conference|Pac-10]]) |attendance= 65, 207 |TV= [[Fox Sports (USA)|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Thom Brennaman]] (playâbyâplay), [[Brian Billick]] (color commentator) }} ==Rankings== {{See also|2009 NCAA Division I FBS football rankings}} {| class="wikitable" style="white-space:nowrap;" |+ Ranking Movement
